narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lecture.
We had three shorter seminars per week and one lecture each week. I particularly enjoyed meeting three times per week because we were able to have more productive discussions with less zoom fatigue.
Pre recorded lecture
recorded lecture

* virtual seminar or other discussion format
* recorded lecture
Pre-recorded lecture
recorded lectures, writing assignments, lecture questions, reading prompts
review sessions with the professor, one on one meetings with the professor.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to interpret and discuss complex philosophical texts, forming my own opinions on the texts instead of just absorbing them. We also worked on the elements necessary to write a philosophy essay, such as argument reconstruction and concept clarification.

Philosophy has been one of my favorite classes so far. I have learned to think critically about the world around me and support any inferences with methodical arguments. Additionally, I have learned how to write a philosophical argument and examine the argument I am trying to make as well as the counter-argument.

DS Philosophy was, as promised, a fast-paced survey of Western philosophy from Plato to Aquinas. The course required critical reading and writing. The course also included philosophical skills, like argument reconstruction, concept clarification, and the resolution of competing textual interpretations.

This course discusses ideas including what is good and what God is. One effect reading these texts had for me was to lead me to think in terms of "insofar" (e.g. if a person is a doctor and heals themselves, insofar as they are a doctor they are performing medicine, not receiving it, whereas insofar as they are a patient they are being healed--a doctor in the precise sense is not healed) and overall I found the course developed the sophistication of our philosophical thinking.
How to make sense of, explain, and construct philosophical arguments.
I learned how to reconstruct philosophy arguments.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strength of this course is how it demanded a high level of engagement with the lectures and the texts, through writing assignments, lecture questions, and challenging topics of in-class discussion. I think at times, however, the seminars focused so much on interpretation and argument about the ideas within the text that I felt confused at times when these texts were more complex  dedicating some time just to basic review of the texts' ideas would have been helpful to make me feel prepared to enter the higher levels of discussion.

I am particularly grateful that this class was taught in a small seminar format because I was able to actively participate and work through arguments in class, as well as listen and respond to my peers. I also enjoyed having class three days per week instead of two because it created more continuity for the class each week. The only improvement I would suggest is that the long-form lectures be offered synchronously so that we can ask questions in real-time as they come up during the lecture.
Of the three DS courses, Philosophy felt the most reasonably paced. It exposed us to a wide variety of writers and philosophical areas.

The writing assignments are very thoughtful and useful. The greatest downfall of the course for me was that there were many good resources (guided reading questions, lectures, and guided listening questions) but I did not have time to do any more than read the texts so I missed out on getting as much as I should have out of the course. Perhaps it is possible to do all of these things in addition to the mere volume of reading but I didn't manage to.
A strength is that we really engage with the texts, and a weakness is that the texts can be hard to understand.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The virtual seminars were very engaging, and managed to recreate a real classroom experience. I think using breakout rooms a bit more often would have been helpful, however, because on the rare times that we did use breakout rooms it seemed to facilitate more engaged and personal discussion.

Having three shorter seminars instead of two longer seminars helped reduce Zoom fatigue and made it easier to stay actively engaged. I also enjoyed being able to work through arguments in breakout rooms. As I mentioned in the previous comment, it would be helpful if the lectures were offered synchronously, so that we could better engage with the material of the lecture as it is presented.
The partitioning of my section into three 50-minute meetings was an excellent decision. As a remote student, I wish deadlines had adjusted to my time zone.

I liked the 3 days per week seminar schedule. It seemed to allow us to better explore more aspects of a week's content by dividing each week's seminar into three distinct settings, and it helped with managing the reading load (the reading was spread out over three seminar days instead of two, which made apportioning easier; also, with the 3 meetings per week, even if you were behind on reading for two days you still had one more chance).
The instructor tended to speak a bit fast which was hard to keep up with virtually.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Although this course had a much higher workload than the other DS courses I took, and tackled complex ideas that often left me initially confused, I think it was a great course as an intensive introduction to college-level philosophy. It really managed to develop my skills in discussing, reading, and writing, and I feel like I have learned so much over the course of the semester.

Yes! After taking Professor Werner's class, I now look at the world through a more logical and critical lens. I didn't realize this would happen, but I even weave philosophy into many of my everyday conversationsciting Aristotle or Plato when contemplating with friends why certain things in this world might be the way they are. Professor Werner's class has left a large impact on me and has inspired me to consider majoring in philosophy.
DS Philosophy was worth the effort it required. I feel that I improved in my argumentative skills, which served me well both in and outside of class.

Yes; I thought the content the instructor provided for the course (the handouts for guided discussion, the writing assignments, the guided listening questions, and likely the guided reading questions as well) was excellent for facilitating our learning.
I would recommend this course to people because it is a good and challenging way to understand the history of philosophy.
